climbs.name: Washed Up Hippie With A Handgun

content.description: Someone must have climbed this in the past, it is too good of a natural system yielding an interesting summit of the first cliffs. Start in offwidth to the right of choo choo. Do not use any bolts. Keep inside offwidth until the very top bumping a #4 or #5 to protect upper portion, making transition to climbers right onto a death flake. flake protects well with micros and nuts up to 0.75 cam. However, it is hollow and flexes and could potentially break in a fall. Regardless, this is an interesting climb, and needs no bolts. Climb to end of flake to quartz vein. 2 bolt belay shared with 'Golden Slippers'.
content.protection: #4 and/or #5. will need to bump if you have only 1 of these pieces. doubles of 2 and 3. micros. 2 bolt belay anchor.
content.location: Offwidth crack system at base of approach trail. Tree growing in offwidth marks the beginning of the route. Right of 'choo choo'.

content.description:
A somewhat pumpy and sustained mixed route that will test your balance and footwork. 

  Pitch 1: Climb a series of horizontals with good gear to a bolt. pull through the bolt (crux move) into the obvious handcrack. Climb the crack to the top trending left over the bulge as the crack runs out (watch the loose blocks on the right). Delicate moves lead you to a ramp, second bolt and rest. Fun face moves and one more bolt will gain the two bolt anchor. *Gear is possible between the last two bolts on the right. (90)
content.protection: Standard Rack and Draws with cams up to size #1.
content.location:
The route starts near the end of the upper tier, approximately 20 to the right of Perdito. A single bolt roughly 20 off the ground marks the start. 

  Rappel the route from the two bolt anchor

content.description: The bolted line up the right hand dihedral and roof system. There is an optional small TCU placement between the first and second bolts. Face climb and stem up the corner, then pull up and right over the roof before stepping back left to the anchor.
content.protection: 4 bolts and gear to a LO anchor. A small alien or TCU is the only piece of gear you'll need, if any.
content.location:
The Attitash Crag has a few distinct and somewhat separate sections: 

  - Lowest on the hillside, and to the left as you face the cliff, is the low-angle slab where Seasonal View, Three Gems and several other good pitches are found. This slab is bordered on its right (uphill) end by a bulging buttress with a steep, bolted arete (The Spinach Arete). 

  - Around to the right from here you pass a broken section of cliff before you arrive beneath a short, low-angle slab leading to a vertical wall with a right facing flake running up its center. This is The Flying Jib. 

  - 50' right of the Jib is a steep buttress jutting out from the main wall; The Torch Buttress. The front face of this formation holds two short pitches: one is still an open project, as far as I know, and the other a bolted corner/arete/roof pitch, Torch. 

  - 25' right of Torch, on the overhanging wall extending back right from the front face of the Torch Buttress, is the crack line of Short Fuse.

climbs.name: Thin Line
climbs.fa: Chris Graham with Dave Penny and Bob Ahearn

content.description:
Difficult and thought provoking moves past the first and second bolt lead to a steep and unrelenting slab protected by two bolts and gear at the midway-point. 

  Pitch 1: Climb past three bolts to a vertical crack/pocket (gear up to .75) midway up the slab. Continue straight up the slab on thin but fun chips and smears to a bolt. The route continues on to a nice balcony where you can get a well deserved shake before the final moves past the last bolt to a two bolt anchor (60)
content.protection: #1 & #.75 Camelot. 5 bolts total to a two bolt anchor.
content.location: This is the second bolted route on the right side of Attitash crag located on a small 100 face. Look for an obvious chimney / shallow corner with a right angling rail at roughly 15 (bolt). The shallow chimney and leaning oak tree marks the start of the route. Rap the route with one 60M rope.

content.description: The route actually begins in the obvious undercling flake to the right of the first bolt. I suggest clipping the first bolt from directly below it before getting onto the flake. Make strenuous moves traversing directly left past the bolt, then follow four more bolts around the arete and up the steep face to an anchor on the right.
content.protection: 5 bolts to a LO anchor
content.location:
The Attitash Crag has a few distinct and somewhat separate sections: 

  - Lowest on the hillside, and to the left as you face the cliff, is the low-angle slab where Seasonal View, Three Gems and several other good pitches are found. This slab is bordered on its right (uphill) end by a bulging buttress with a steep, bolted arete (The Spinach Arete). 

  - Around to the right from here you pass a broken section of cliff before you arrive beneath a short, low-angle slab leading to a vertical wall with a right facing flake running up its center. This is The Flying Jib. 

  - 50' right of the Jib is a steep buttress jutting out from the main wall; The Torch Buttress. The front face of this formation holds two short pitches: one is still an open project, as far as I know, and the other a bolted corner/arete/roof pitch, Torch. 

  - 25' right of Torch, on the overhanging wall extending back right from the front face of the Torch Buttress, is the crack line of Short Fuse.

content.description: Climb up, two bolts, to large ledge.  Continue up through crux to 3rd bolt and into corner.   Clip the bolt on the arete and head up and right. Pass two more bolts to the anchor (two bolts, with rings).
content.protection: 5 bolts + 2 bolts at anchor (with rings)
content.location: Far left end of the main wall, about 10 feet to the right of Menethesis, start a few feet to the left of a large oak (helpful for belayer to clip to as the slope is annoying).

content.description:
Start just 10' feet right of the start of Torch (the bolted corner/roof), and climb diagonally right up the easy corner/ramp to the thin, overhanging crack on the left wall. Excellent and difficult jamming lead up the enjoyable set of finger and hand cracks to a tree anchor. 

  Rope anchor probably needs replacing if it hasn't been since '99.
content.protection: Light rack up to a big hand-sized piece. Tree anchor.
content.location:
The Attitash Crag has a few distinct and somewhat separate sections: 

  - Lowest on the hillside, and to the left as you face the cliff, is the low-angle slab where Seasonal View, Three Gems and several other good pitches are found. This slab is bordered on its right (uphill) end by a bulging buttress with a steep, bolted arete (The Spinach Arete). 

  - Around to the right from here you pass a broken section of cliff before you arrive beneath a short, low-angle slab leading to a vertical wall with a right facing flake running up its center. This is The Flying Jib. 

  - 50' right of the Jib is a steep buttress jutting out from the main wall; The Torch Buttress. The front face of this formation holds two short pitches: one is still an open project, as far as I know, and the other a bolted corner/arete/roof pitch, Torch. 

  - 25' right of Torch, on the overhanging wall extending back right from the front face of the Torch Buttress, is the crack line of Short Fuse.

content.description: Start with a couple of bouldery moves past two bolts on a short steep wall with a detached flake. Move up trending left on a lower-angle section, and back right for a vertical finish on great holds, to the right of the sharp arete.
content.protection: 8 bolts to anchor (last bolt somewhat hidden left of the arete, long quickdraw useful)
content.location: Near the middle of the wall past the Flying Jib, 20 feet to the right of Alice's Ballroom corner.

content.description: Climb the delicate slab up to the vertical finish.
content.protection: Bolted.
content.location: Furthest left route on the cliff

climbs.name: Moonriver
climbs.fa: Ben Miller and John Halupowski, July 20, 2016

content.description: Climb the face, through a bulge midway up, passing seven bolts along the way.    Generally moderate climbing with occasional thinner moves peppered in.  Finished by the light of a full moon on a warm July night.
content.protection: Bolts, with double rap rings at the top belay.
content.location: Twenty feet right of Life of Brian. (Currently [ 2018 ]  the furthest right, cleaned rock on the slab. )

climbs.name: Menethesis
climbs.fa: Joe & Judy Perez, Mona L'Heureux, & John Snyder July 1995

content.description: A fun, well protected route. Crux moves are clipping the anchor.
content.protection: 6 bolts and a bugaboo with a 2 bolt anchor with rap rings
content.location: Located at the far right end of the Main Cliff, 60 feet past the large left facing corner of Perdito. Start on a small platform with a horizontal crack 6 feet off the ground and above a small tree growing close to the cliff.

content.description: A bouldery start gets you to the first bolt. Easy moves to the second. Very balancy and perplexing moves get you past the first crux and to a good stance. A second crux awaits you after clipping the fourth and final bolt which lands you onto a nice stance. From this stance it is roughly 20' to a two bolt anchor with rings.
content.protection:
4 bolts to a two bolt anchor. There is a nice vertical slot for a small cam on the ledge just after the last bolt (optional)but not a bad idea. 

  Rappel the route from the two bolt anchor
content.location:
This was once the farthest route to the right of Attitash Crag located on a small 80' face that is roughly 100' in length. 

  [NOTE: See COMMENTs on the route Thin Line for more beta on LOCATION. R Hall, Admin.]

climbs.name: Life of Brian
climbs.fa: Ben Miller and John Halupowski, May 17, 2016

content.description: Varied face climbing with smears, crystals and knobs.  There is a big slot between the third and fourth bolts, not visible from the ground, that takes a medium cam and offers secure jams while reaching the fourth bolt.  Moderate climbing to the first bolt, twenty feet off the ground.  For our friend Brian Skelding.
content.protection: Five bolts, one medium cam.  Two bolt anchor with rings to rap or lower off, or walk off.
content.location: This route is right of A Bolt Too Far.  There is a fallen tree at the base,  and a large oak tree stands between the bases of this route and A Bolt Too Far.

climbs.name: Lichen Runs Through It
climbs.fa: Joe & Judy Perez, Ben Onachila, Scott Mc Intyre March 1994

content.description: A nice well protected climb on good rock with thin moves at the last two bolts.
content.protection: 5 Bolts with a 2 bolt/rap ring anchor.
content.location: Located at the far right end of the slab just before the big left facing Double Corner route.

content.description: This is the climb just to the right of the off width on the larger main wall near the approach.  Follow the line of bolts up.  Once you surmount the bulge protection runs out.  You can place smaller pro in an obvious flake or just run it out to the top.  Your choice.
content.protection: Six bolts.  Anchors at the top.
content.location: Just right of the offwidth with the tree that greets you as come up the the approach gully.

content.description: This a really nice moderate climb up one of the taller sections of the cliff.   Positive holds in the lower sections gradually peter out leading to a fun thin cruxy section before the angle lessons.  The top section is easy but a little runout.
content.protection: 7 bolts. The bolts are nicely spaced.  I saw little option for additional pro.  Bolt anchors with rings at the top.
content.location: This route is the second bolted route to the right of the off-width that greets climbers as they arrive at the crag.  It is just to the left of an uncleared swathe of rock with some bolts in it (Bear Crossing).

content.description:
Angle up the dirty slab from the right to reach the base of the obvious flake. Clip a bolt, then pull up into the flake and follow it to two more bolts which protect the final, crux face moves. 

  This thing was thoroughly cleaned ten years ago; dunno what it looks like now.
content.protection: Three bolts, stoppers, and some medium cams will get you to a two-bolt LO anchor.
content.location:
The Attitash Crag has a few distinct and somewhat separate sections: 

  - Lowest on the hillside, and to the left as you face the cliff, is the low-angle slab where Seasonal View, Three Gems and several other good pitches are found. This slab is bordered on its right (uphill) end by a bulging buttress with a steep, bolted arete (The Spinach Arete). 

  - Around to the right from here you pass a broken section of cliff before you arrive beneath a short, low-angle slab leading to a vertical wall with a right facing flake running up its center. This is The Flying Jib. 

  - 50' right of the Jib is a steep buttress jutting out from the main wall; The Torch Buttress. The front face of this formation holds two short pitches: one is still an open project, as far as I know, and the other a bolted corner/arete/roof pitch, Torch. 

  - 25' right of Torch, on the overhanging wall extending back right from the front face of the Torch Buttress, is the crack line of Short Fuse.

climbs.name: Dukes of Hazard aka Three Gems
climbs.fa: Randy Gagne and James St. Jean 1991, accidentaly retroed and renamed in 1994

content.description: Climb the bouldery start to a delicate layback up a thin left-arcing crack.  Come face-to-face with the crux bulge and pull past two bolts on steeper terrain to a two-bolt anchor.
content.protection: Nuts, Small cams, and two draws.
content.location: Second route from the cliff's left side.

content.description: Climb a short, blocky section to a horizontal crack (cam), climb right to a welcomed bolt about 20' up. Pass a 2nd bolt to a beautiful left trending flake. At top of crack step right to a bolt. Climb pass 2 more bolts on a steep face to a 2 bolt rap anchor.
content.protection: 5 bolts, rack to 2.5", 2 bolt rap anchor
content.location: Start just right of the left facing corner of Perdito.

content.description:
This is the first climb encountered and maybe the easiest on the cliff.  Head straight up the slab following an obvious line of 4 bolts.  Straying into the off-width on the right probably lowers the grade a bit.  

  You'll understand the name if climb there long enough in the summer months.
content.protection: 4 draws plus bolt anchor at the top.   The bolts are judiciously placed but a smaller crack in the back of the off-width allows for some supplementary protection for the faint of heart.
content.location: Choo Choo ascends the low angle bolted face just left off the wide crack with the tree growing on the left side of the crag.  This crack is likely the first thing you will see as you arrive at the cliff.   Dukes of Hazard (aka Three Gems) is further to the left of this climb.  .

content.description:
Start directly in front of the large oak tree, about 15 ft Left of "Bear" and 10-12 ft Right of "Golden Slippers".

 The current guidebook designates this a "trad" climb...perhaps the bolts are too far apart to qualify as "sport". The book also lists it as "5.8". I thought a bit harder and posted it as such. We'll let "consensus" determine the grade.

 Climb up the bolted line (holds brushed 2015), passing the place where a flake broke off (before or after the grade of 5.8, per guidebook, was established?) cross over "Bear" and finish in the "groove".

 2018 update - currently the abundance of oak sap from the huge tree has given the lichen plenty of food and the climb is in need of another brushing, although the holds are cleaner than the surrounding rock.
content.protection: Draws

climbs.name: Bear
climbs.fa: Judy & Joe Perez, Ben Onachila, May 1994

content.description: Fun climbing straight up the slab just right of the presently heavy lichened Bear Crossing. The 4 bolts above the dike seem a little left of the best holds and the natural line so the clips maybe a little awkward. If you lead the route straight up by the bolts it feels 5.9, if you use the better holds to the right it's 5.8.
content.protection: 8 Bolts. There is a 2 bolt/rings rap anchor.
content.location: The climb starts about 40' right of the approach trail just past a large Oak tree below a right slanting dike that passes through mid route.

climbs.name: A Bolt Too Far
climbs.fa: Judy and Joe Perez.  Ben Onchila.  1994

content.description: Thin, delicate, face/slab climbing up past 8 bolts.  The bolts gradually peter out as you reach an odd quartz vein that can be followed easily but a little iffily to the top.  Very fun climb some call 5.10, some call sustained 5.9 without true crux.
content.protection: Eight bolts.
content.location: This is on the same face as How Green Was My Valley and Golden Slippers.  This one starts right of the tree and right of the obvious dike.  Currently its the last cleaned route on the right of the face.  It trends right.

climbs.name: Alice's Ballroom
climbs.fa: Judy Perez, Mike Cummings and Joe Perez, May 2006

content.description: go up a slab past a small diagonal bulge to gain the bottom of a short steep wall and a right-facing corner. Climb the corner and the face to its right.
content.protection: Bolts.
content.location: About eighty feet past the Flying Jib, look for a narrow slab with a few bolts below the obvious right-facing corner.

content.description: This is the main original cliff band at Attitash.
